title: Quiz 4: Curriculum Development & Design
topicName: Health Education Unit Five: Teaching and Learning Methodologies
description: Assess your understanding of curriculum components, influencing factors, and development models.

questions.question: What is the most accurate definition of a 'Curriculum'?

options.text: A list of books to be read
A description of all activities and events in a training programme from start to finish

questions.explanation: A curriculum is comprehensive, covering everything (content, methods, assessment, experiences) likened to a 'racecourse'.
questions.hint: It covers everything from day 1 to graduation.

questions.question: Which of the following are essential components of a curriculum document? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Detailed lesson plans for every single lecture

questions.explanation: A curriculum outlines the framework (goals, content, assessment) but usually not every specific daily lesson plan.
questions.hint: Think of the big picture document.

questions.question: Match the factor influencing curriculum development with its description:

pairs.right: Relevance to local needs, culture, and disease patterns (e.g., HIV)
Available funds determining the level/type of training possible
Government decisions on numbers to train or quota systems
Current trends, new theories, and research in the discipline

questions.explanation: Social = Community needs; Economic = Money/Resources; Political = Policy/Power; Academic = Subject knowledge.
questions.hint: Money vs. Community vs. Government vs. Knowledge.

questions.question: The process of determining exactly what knowledge, attitudes, and skills a graduate needs to perform a specific job function is called ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Task analysis involves breaking down a job role into specific tasks to inform curriculum content.

questions.question: Which approach to curriculum development focuses on identifying professional roles and the specific skills needed to perform them?
questions.explanation: Competency-based education (CBE) focuses on the outcomes—what the learner can DO (competencies)—rather than just what they know.

questions.question: Curriculum development is solely the responsibility of the teachers within the institution; external stakeholders should not be involved.
questions.explanation: Curriculum development is a cooperative process. External participants (community, employers, NGOs) are crucial for ensuring relevance.
questions.hint: Do we write a curriculum for the community without asking them?

questions.question: Place the first 5 steps of the 'Competency-Based Curriculum Development Process' in the correct order:

items.text: Identification of health problems or needs
Identification of professional roles and functions
Development of educational goals and objectives

questions.hint: Start with WHY we are training (health needs).

questions.question: What is the main disadvantage of the 'Subject-centred Approach' to curriculum development?

options.text: It emphasizes acquisition of disciplined knowledge rather than its application
It is too cheap to implement

questions.explanation: Subject-centred curricula often compartmentalize knowledge (e.g., pure Anatomy, pure Physiology) without showing how to apply it to real patient problems.

questions.question: Name one category of 'Internal Participants' in curriculum development.
questions.explanation: Internal participants include teachers, students, administrators, and exam boards—those directly involved in the training institution.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the 'Integrated Approach' to curriculum?

options.text: Combines knowledge from different disciplines meaningfully
Focuses on wholesome learning for application
Removes all basic sciences from the course

questions.explanation: Integration merges related disciplines (e.g., teaching anatomy and physiology of the heart together) to improve understanding.
